qas.question: When did the US Court of Appeals rule in the case of ACLU v. Mercer County?
What was displayed in Kentucky courthouses?
Why were the displays of the ten Commandments allowed?
When was a ruling handed down on the Mount Soledad cross controversy?
What did a federal judge rule must be removed from public property?
When did the US Court of Appeals not rule in the case of ACLU v. Mercer County?
What was not displayed in Kentucky courthouses?
Why were the displays of the ten Commandments disallowed?
When was a ruling not handed down on the Mount Soledad cross controversy?
What did a federal judge rule must be removed from private property?

context: On <a0_0><b5_0>December 20, 2005<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled in the case of ACLU v. Mercer County that the continued display of <a1_0>the <b6_0>Ten Commandments<b6_0/><a1_0/> as part of a larger display on American legal traditions in a Kentucky courthouse was allowed, because the purpose of the display (educating the public on American legal traditions) was <a2_0><b7_0>secular in nature<b7_0/><a2_0/>. In ruling on the Mount Soledad cross controversy on <a3_0><b8_0>May 3, 2006<b8_0/><a3_0/>, however, a federal judge ruled that <a4_0>the <b9_0>cross<b9_0/><a4_0/> on public property on Mount Soledad must be removed.
